Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Application of a Bottom-up Approach to Study Bio-adhesives Molecular Conformation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1308728 (Fini). This project will evaluate the feasibility of using molecular dynamics simulation to understand how molecular conformation affects bio-adhesive?s basic mechanical behavior, including its modulus, viscosity, and adhesion. To provide the most realistic molecular structural information for modeling, a bio-adhesive with specified mechanical properties will be produced using thermochemical liquefaction and fractionation, a method recently developed by the PI. Then, the chemical compounds in and the molecular structure of bio-adhesive will be characterized using XRD, NMR and AFM. This information will be used to develop the molecular model for MD simulation. The molecular structures of bio-adhesive will be constructed using the major molecular compounds identified in the bio-adhesive. Based on the results of the laboratory experiments and the molecular models, the relation between the chemical make-up of bio-adhesive and its rheology will be established. Such knowledge will help identify the fundamental mechanisms which control the mechanical behavior of bio-adhesives including adhesion, fracture energy and toughness. The results will be further used to determine the chemical compounds in bio-adhesives which positively or negatively affect mechanical behavior. This, in turn, can provide in-depth knowledge on how distillation parameters should be controlled in order to produce bio-adhesives with specified rheology and mechanical characteristics. The outcome of this project could support the use of the 40.2 million tons of swine manure produced annually in the U.S. to supply about 28 million tons of bio-adhesive. This bio-adhesive can be used for industrial carpeting, packaging, soil stabilization, crack sealing, roofing and pavement construction as well as fertilizer coating applications. This, in turn, can improve manure management practices by sequestering carbon from manure into bio-adhesive while using its nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium as a pathogen-free liquid fertilizer.Therefore, the project can lead to major, positive environmental and economic impacts in both the agricultural and construction sectors.

Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this EAGER project was to investigate feasibility of applying a bottom-up approach using molecular dynamics (MD) simulation to examine effects of intermolecular interactions within a bio-adhesive (made from bio-mass) and their impacts on bituminous binder thermo-mechanical properties.

The research results showed that the bio-adhesives molecules were able to alter conformation of asphaltene molecules, and blend well in bitumen matrix. Furthermore, increase of fracture energy of the asphaltene matrix upon introduction of specific molecular species of bio-adhesive was evident. This was attributed to surfactant role of some of bio-adhesive molecules. The study results showed that some of bio-adhesives’ molecular species, specifically those with polar tail interact well with asphaltene molecules and have relatively high coefficient of diffusion. In addition, as temperature increases, diffusion of amide-rich species into the asphaltene sheets increases promoting their enhnacement effect.Study of intermolecular interactions using molecular dynamics simulation further showed that amide groups in bio-adhesive interact with asphaltene and increase the stacking distance of asphaltene dimers while altering conformation packing.

In addition, the impact of the project was reflected in its contribution to both agriculture and construction industry by producing construction adhesives from bio-mass waste. Specifically, the outcome of this project can allow 40.2 million tons of swine manure produced annually in the U.S. to be used to supply about 28 million tons of bio-adhesive for industrial carpeting, packaging, soil stabilization, crack sealing, roofing and pavement construction as well as fertilizer coating applications. Therefore, successful implementation of this project would provide a molecular based synthesis platform to convert other bio waste to added value products such as bio-adhesives.  This in turn can increase profitability of agriculture industry by creating marginal revenue from their waste stream, while providing raw material resources for construction industry and offering sustainable waste management solutions for environmental protection.


Last Modified: 03/25/2017
Modified by: Elham Fini
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this EAGER project was to investigate feasibility of applying a bottom-up approach using molecular dynamics (MD) simulation to examine effects of intermolecular interactions within a bio-adhesive (made from bio-mass) and their impacts on bituminous binder thermo-mechanical properties. The research results showed that the bio-adhesives molecules were able to alter conformation of asphaltene molecules, and blend well in bitumen matrix. Furthermore, increase of fracture energy of the asphaltene matrix upon introduction of specific molecular species of bio-adhesive was evident. This was attributed to surfactant role of some of bio-adhesive molecules. The study results showed that some of bio-adhesives? molecular species, specifically those with polar tail interact well with asphaltene molecules and have relatively high coefficient of diffusion. In addition, as temperature increases, diffusion of amide-rich species into the asphaltene sheets increases promoting their enhnacement effect.Study of intermolecular interactions using molecular dynamics simulation further showed that amide groups in bio-adhesive interact with asphaltene and increase the stacking distance of asphaltene dimers while altering conformation packing. In addition, the impact of the project was reflected in its contribution to both agriculture and construction industry by producing construction adhesives from bio-mass waste. Specifically, the outcome of this project can allow 40.2 million tons of swine manure produced annually in the U.S. to be used to supply about 28 million tons of bio-adhesive for industrial carpeting, packaging, soil stabilization, crack sealing, roofing and pavement construction as well as fertilizer coating applications. Therefore, successful implementation of this project would provide a molecular based synthesis platform to convert other bio waste to added value products such as bio-adhesives. This in turn can increase profitability of agriculture industry by creating marginal revenue from their waste stream, while providing raw material resources for construction industry and offering sustainable waste management solutions for environmental protection.
